title: The CLARIN Language Resource Switchboard

author: Claus Zinn, Department of Linguistics, University of Tübingen

segmentation: Yeah hello.
I'm going to present the Clarion language Resource Switchboard, which I think has the potential to become a new pillar for declaring infrastructure.
I will start with the motivation behind the switchboard.
Walk you through the system using a couple of screenshots.
Discuss the architecture of the switchboard and.
At the end, discuss some open issues and conclude.
OK, so.
Clearing offers its users.
Access to a wide range of language resources.
There is, of course the Virtual Language Observatory which you all know where users can perform search based on metadata to find the sources of their interest.
There is the Federated content search where you can perform full text search on resources.
But once you have found your resource of interest, I think most of you would like to do something with the resource in one way or the other.
And for this you need tools for the time being.
There is no such thing like say the virtual tool Observatory which gives you access to all the tools of the client community.
And there are a number of tools that are available to switch port.
Feels appan this idea of this virtual tool registry, but it seems to be a little bit more.
Motivation is that if you have identified the source of your interest, the switch port would like to just would like to suggest you tools which you can use to process your resource.
So the idea is.
You have the resource.
That you make.
It may make known to the switchboard.
The switchboard does a magic, identifies all the tools that are available in the current community.
They can do something with your resource.
You select tool in question and then the switchboard starts the tool for you with the resource you have in mind.
OK.
So.
So how does it look like here?
You see and the standalone version of the switchboard which we have used as as our main development vehicle.
But it seems that it's quite popular and it will stay.
But you can do if they stand alone version you you take your resource from your file system and drag and drop it into this dotted area.
Right and what happens then?
Is on on this page and information pane opens, which tells you what the switchboard knows about your resource.
It knows the file name.
It knows the file size, but it also tries to deduce from the resources from the resource it's mimetype and the language the resources in.
What happens also as a side effect, is that your resource from your file from your local file system is uploaded to a centralized server.
Because the tool that is going to process your resource need access to the resource and it's going to fetch the resource from this from this upload server.
Of course the switchboard can be wrong with using the language and the MIME type, so the user has to put possibility to correct this information.
There's a pop down menu where you choose the correct language and to correct my pipe.
With textual with plain text files it's quite accurate, but with other file formats like PDF or word documents, sometimes the language it uses is just wrong.

OK, you also notice there's a little switch and there is a button show tools if you if you activate the switch the button will change to show tools and web services because we also recently included web services in our tool registry.
So what you do is you click on show tools.
Once you are happy with the information you provided.
And then the policy will show you the list of all tools that could do something with your resource.
And it's a task oriented you.
So there is a task, for instance tokenization or lemmatization voice synthesis.
And there are in total it doesn't have tasks that we have currently in tools that can do a dozen of tasks that you have registered with the with the switchboard.
So let's say you want to do lemmatization.
You can click on on one of those two tools that offer such service, and when you open, when you click on such a tool like web list, you get.
More information about the tool, its name, a short description, some contact information, and the the button Click to start tool.
And here is where the magic happens.
You click on Start tool and then.
At least opens, but it doesn't open in a standard way.

It opens at the right point in time where placed has magically downloaded resource from the upload server and it has selected the correct easy chain for tokenization and all you have to do is press the start button.
And that works for all the other tools that we have integrated into the switchboard.
So that's really nice.
OK. And.
This was the standalone version, but the version that we have integrated with the speech board with the with the below works basically the same.
And it's already operational, so if you're in the yellow, you might have notice these little dots once you have selected a record and all the resources associated with the record.
If you click on the three dots, you get this process with the switchboard information you click on it.
And then you're back to the slide where your resource will show up in the switchboard.
You can correct information.
You can select your tools charger to land and off you go.

Sudie architecture.

It has this resource information pane and then you have the list of all applicable tools.
Uh, let's look at it back and it has three main components.
One component is the tool registry where we ask a tool developers to send US metadata that describes the tools.
And I will show you an example of such 2 metadata in a minute.
Then there's the profiler.
The profiler is the component that is responsible for identifying relevant metadata from the source.
That we need to find applicable tools.
Right not all tools can do everything if every resource they can only do stuff with certain resources of certain types.
And the profiler tries to identify this information.

From the resource or from available metadata about the resource and then in the middle there is the matter who brings together the information computed by the profiler and the information that is available in the in the tool registry and tries to compute the list of all applicable tools.
For the time being.
And the profile is relatively simple.
It only looks for the mimetype of the resource and the language resources in other information might be necessary or will be necessary.
Maybe in the future, but that's what they are currently using.
So the match is also relatively simple.
It also has to look for those pieces of information in the tool metadata and nothing else.
And the app registry is just a set of of metadata.
Which is basically a data structure.
OK.
So a bit of technology.
Yeah, the app registry is is a Jason data structure list of of attribute value pairs.
The matter is simple JavaScript.
As I said, only using mimetype and language as the two main criteria to find applicable tools and the profiler.
And is also relatively simple when the switchboard is called from the vlog, the vlog parses metadata to the switchboard.
Because the below has the metadata about the source, so from the vlog we get the MIME type and the language.
This might not always be correct.
I will come to that later.
In the standalone version, we don't have metadata, you just drag and drop resource into this shop area.
So we have.
And mind type detection in place and we have a language detection in place using Apache ticker libraries.
And of course there's user intervention where the users can correct the information if if our detection returns to wrong results.
OK, here you see an example of a tool entry for the switch port.

But there's also information, of course.

For on on documents in Word format.
You also see at last at the bottom of the tracing structure parameters.
Here you hear you specify what kind of parameters should the switchboard center the tool say to well placed so that the tool starts at the right time.
Right, of course we pass on the input.
You know, if reference to the resource where the tool can download the resource, but we also hear about place we pass on the language information and the analysis information.
So very pleased.
Wants to see analysis as a parameter and the word me and will do named entity recognition if if we start with named entity recognition.
If called such parametrisation.
OK, some tools may like other parameters to be in past we try to minimize the adoption efforts required by two providers to get registered with the switchboard.
So here you see a mapping where the parameters are mapped to the parameters of the systems.
Understand they don't have to change their parameters, the switch would does that for you.
OK.
Here's an example of how backlist is this invoked.
Yeah, you see a reference to file some encoding of the MIME type and the language.
And that's what usually the tools gets from the switchboard.
OK, a bit about the state of the of the switch port.
We have 35 tools currently registered after Switch port and we have a dozen of web services.
We are very close to the end of the implementation phase end of October.
There will be of course some time left to improve the switchboard.
The integration with the Federated Content Search and the Virtual Collection registry is still to be done.
That's mostly work on their side, not on the switchboard site.
And of course we would like to increase the participation of more tools, need serious usability testing and take this input into account to iteratively improve.
The switchboard yeah, there are a couple of open issues, maybe I don't talk about all six of them.
Let me take two or three out of them.
There is a data curation aspect that has an impact on the usability.
So sometimes the below has wrong information about metadata about the source.
Say the mimetype you.
In the in the below, it says that resource is a plain text file, but in reality it's not playing.
It's invested some kind of annotations.

Of course, if you start passing this to the switchboard and this which puts all applicable tools and then you start the tools and when you look at the tool results then you figure out how it actually was, not plain text.
It was something else.
So that's that's something which which has a negative impact on the usability, Accessibility, legal and privacy.
Sometimes you pass a resource to the switchboard.
You look at all applicable tools, you select one and then two.

The two tries to download the source, but then the tool is not allowed to download the resource, but doesn't have the missing credentials or you would like to start a tool, but you don't have the access if you don't have to write the proper rights to start the tools.
Right, so we have to figure out some user allocation issues.
With that yeah, maybe interoperability as the very last point here.
Which was task is really simple.
Just identify applicable tools you select.
Once you start it and that's where the switchboard task end.
Why there is no communication between the switchboard and the tool the switch but doesn't know if the tool was successful.
It doesn't get anything back from the tool, it just opens in a new browser tab and.
New York City food is ignorant of of what happens that might want to.
We might want to change that in the future, but they're not really working together in the sense of.
More than what I just said.
And that might.
But that is an issue that we might address.
OK, so I'd like to invite you to the Bazaar.
This afternoon will give you a demo of the switch for the life demo, given the advice he works.
I like to encourage all the developers to consider their tools for integration with the switchboard.

There's not too much adaption that you have to do other than understanding URL parameters that are passed on to you and then figuring out how you make your tool advance to state such that the user doesn't have to enter all the information again.
I also encourage you to use the standalone version and give me feedback as much as possible.
OK, thank you very much.
